>>178974158
Either a man or a woman can be king or queen
But whoever is actually in the line of succession gets the title
Elizabeth was queen because Philip was Danish-Greek, so he had the title of prince or king-consort
Charles is king because he is the queen's son, so Camilla has the title princess or queen-consort
Basically whoever is the monarch gets the full title. Whoever they're married to gets prince/princess and king-consort/queen-consort
We got rid of the whole "the throne goes to the eldest male relative" centuries ago because it caused too many wars with Europe, especially if that relative was Catholic (England has had a long and bad history with Popery, which is when the Pope has the final say in English matters)

>>178976717
It's certainly one of the oldest, but idk if it is the oldest. We got it from the Danes who invaded England and ruled half the country. The Danes appointed Jarls to pacify areas that were 50:50 English:Danish. When we reconquered those areas we Anglicised it to Eorl who had the exact same job (usually it was the same bloke in charge too, we just paid him more). Eventually Eorl became Earl as the language evolved.

Legal troubles
In March 2015, police responded to an alleged assault by Lloyd on his mother Lisa Riley. In a statement to the Indianapolis Metro Police Department, Riley alleged Lloyd arrived at her house and began verbally berating her. He then progressed to physically assaulting her, but she declined to press charges, revealing that Lloyd had been diagnosed with schizophrenia and was not taking his medication at the time.[8]

On June 17, 2015, Lloyd was arrested in South Carolina under the name Jake Broadbent for reckless driving, driving without a license, and resisting arrest; he failed to stop for a red light, which initiated a high-speed police chase.[9][10][11] At a hearing on June 22, his bail was set at $10,700.[12] On June 23, Lloyd's mother stated to TMZ that he has schizophrenia and that "the family plans to try and get him help again [...] once he's released from jail".[8] Lloyd was not released on bail.[citation needed]

In April 2016, after being held for 10 months awaiting trial in Colleton County Detention Center, Lloyd was transferred from jail to a psychiatric facility due to his schizophrenia diagnosis.[13][14]

In January 2020, his family issued a statement saying that he has moved closer to his family, and has officially been diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia.[14][15]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: There's a lot wrong with the sequels but the biggest fault is how little room there was for an expanded universe. There's no new appealing aliens, no interesting locations, barely any planets that aren't empty, no new vehicles that aren't rehashed, no new factions, there's just nothing that sparks wonder or imagination. The sequel universe seems tiny whereas the prequels make the universe feels massive, like there was an unlimited potential for stories to be told. And those stories were told through really great games, tv shows, and books. That's the biggest reason the prequels have so many defenders after two decades, the expanded universe fills all of the gaps left by the movies.

I loved the scene when he was absolutely losing it underwater before starting the attack. Literal cgi whale conveying more raw emotion than most live action human characters these days. They had no need for that, and a lesser director would've just showed him spotting the kids, squinting his eye, and then popping up out the water, but Cameron made it something genuinely personal and epic in scale with that freakout powerup scene. There's also a really cool shot that lasts like 5-10 seconds showing him wrap the harpoon cord around his horns after dodging it. Something about the angle of the camera, the way he moves forward and turns around, and the way the shot doesn't cut until he's got the cord wrapped feels so fucking threatening and kino. Really did a great job actually showing the whale having a personality and planning.

He's fantastic. But on the topic of AI, you know his famous quote about advanced tech and magic? I think maybe Cameron's making his own addendum to it:

>Any sufficiently advanced technology would have the appearance of nature.

Given the direction our own tech is heading in, I agree with him. I think Pandora is what you get when a staggeringly advanced civilization integrates their tech with nature. What I said in >>178976876 about Jake being gnostically Luciferian has to do with that whole idea of "God"(Eywa) being either a selfish deity or a "tough parent." In certain gnostic traditions, Lucifer is seen as a figure who brought free will and knowledge by encouraging Eve to take of the forbidden fruit. Depending on the tradition, he's wittingly or unwittingly doing the will of the Creator God or an even higher power.

My take is that Eywa is a sort of protector and gatekeeper who that higher power absolutely intends to eventually be defied. I think she's there to keep the Na'vi primitive while they culturally and spiritually mature.

posts.com:
I think people take Cameron's directing for granted when it comes the way he choreographs and frames all movement, and he doesn't get enough credit for it. Every single set piece in the film is so deliberately filmed without looking overly "blocked" in an inorganic way that you get the best of both world - it looks both real as though they actuality filmed it live action but also very well choreographed so that everything is clear and the action has super great readability. He's so consistent and good at it that people don't even notice it.

Like when the ship is turning over, I was thinking about inception and how, the hallway run is a great moment in the film where you can clearly see what Nolan was going for, but then the fight in the suite when Joseph Gordon Levitt and the enemy guy are fighting with all this paper flying everywhere, that part looks like dogshit because there's just no thought put into storyboarding it. With the ship turning over, the entire sequence is as well done as the part with neytiri and tuk climbing up the tables in that cafeteria style room as the whole place turns around and the water changes levels. It's not like that one part of the sequence is well done and the rest are quick cuts masking everything to hide the dogshit. No its literally firing on all cylinders the whole way through. I know he won't win but he definitely deserves to be nominated for best director.

>>178977940
That's my point. A lot of hacks think that to make a villain they have to make him corrupt, and Jim didn't fall for that trap.
Instead he made a G.I. Joe action figure and puzzled out the way to make this Real American Hero into a believable antagonist without betraying what a Joe is at his core.
The result was Quaritch. A hero, a soldier, as honorable as one can be during a war, whose only known grudge was against the protagonist for what is undebatably his betrayal.
Of course, Jake wasn't evil either. He saw how corrupt the RDA was and got out of there out of an infatuation of Pandora and its people, not least of all Neytiri, of whom he fell in full blown love. Quaritch also saw RDA's corruption but swore an oath that defined him, and unlike Jake believed that the RDA despite its flaws worked toward the greater good of humanity. So not only did betrayal pit Quaritch against Sully, but also his own loyal bond, a bond that he made years before, that he had no intention of breaking.
Therein lies the loophole. The new Quaritch, with all of his memories, didn't physically swear this oath. My guess is it'll eventually hit him that he isn't bound to the RDA the way his human body was, but I digress.
My point is that Quaritch, like most Avatar characters, is a simple template given complexity from being blended into the narrative. That he wasn't originally written with complexity in mind, ended up fleshing him out more naturally. He always had character in Avatar. In Way of Water, his character has more room to develop further.

Virtue signalling is helped by having large groups of people but it isn't required. If I am in a large group of people and I want to appear to be more virtuous than anyone else, I can invent a new way (or nearly new way) to show that I am the most virtuous. The entire point of my idea is that when you have a communication line to the rest of the planet, you are almost guaranteed to find the validation you are looking for, so the risk is much lower.

Which implies that if you're working class, it's your personal failing as an individual. You were stupid and ignorant and lazy and you're reaping what you sowed.

So this conversation is framed around a direct causal link between the value of your labour and your quality as an individual. Successful, high-value labourers are smart, hard-working, good people, unsuccessful, low-value labourers are not.

So my reply is making the point that labour, and its value, exists within the nation-state's framework (ie, peoples' labour doesn't necessarily have intrinsic value, only relative value within the society and the market), and that the nation-state itself, responsible for the raising of productive individuals, often fails those individuals, specifically in this case in the quality of their education.

No, no one is going to let you get away with claiming the NZ Labour party - or any other major Left-leaning political party in the Western world - wants to significantly reduce immigration levels just because they might temporarily have very slightly lower (though still historically astronomical) levels than the Liberal Right.

To say that UK Labour is a party that ideologically wants to significantly reduce immigration is incorrect and dishonest, even if levels under the Tories have technically been higher.

Likewise in NZ, both your major parties favor historically high levels of immigration. It is dishonest and incorrect to claim otherwise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's no point to it, is there? There's no meaning to it. Closely linked societies no longer exist, at least in the west. Neighbors are suspicious of each other. People don't answer the phone anymore. The doorbell rings and people hide behind the couch. The cost of everything won't stop skyrocketing, as the wages remain the same. Every day is the same. You do the same things, think the same things, see the same things, and desire the same things. Okay, you got a good job, now what? Wake up at the same time. Eat the same breakfast. Sit at the same desk. Repeat ad nauseum. Nothing ever changes. You never grow. You were told that your future held something great, but you finally made it here and there's nothing but the same endless grind towards nothing. You're anxious about this. Worried about that. Will I be able to make rent? Can I afford these groceries? And then you go outside and your car won't start.

Maybe it was always like this, maybe it wasn't. But maybe it never really mattered anyway.

>>178973661
It isn't. It's mind-numbingly boring. The first year I lost like thirty pounds and got jacked. Legit people thought I was Jason Mamoa in there. Then I got really depressed when I didn't get my judicial and I put on like sixty pounds. Kept working out, but started eating less healthy. The food in there is absolute garbage. They had this fake onions meat they would make into everything, like they would form it into patties and sausages and claim it was all kinds of meat but it always tasted the same, no seasoning either so everything tasted like shit. I was in a camp, so there's no privacy. You're on a bunk bed surrounded by other bunkbeds in every direction and there's cameras everywhere. I'd take like fifty minute showers just for the privacy. I'm not religious but I'd attend services just for the peace. I read nearly every book in the library, took college courses just to pass the time, tried to get into the dog walking program but got rejected. Like 40% of the inmates are flaming gay. They let you order certain shit from catalogs and books and such from Amazon, but they wouldn't even let me order a pillow. Even in the "well-behaved" pod violence was a constant. I went fucking primal mode in there. I felt like some little lapdog that got abandoned in the jungle and had to remember how to be wild. Everyone's a con man in there, either trying to get money or ass. And I came out of there way more racist than I went in because you're exclusively around all the niggers that are the basis for all their negative stereotypes. The cable system was shit, don't for a moment think prison is comfy. You don't want to go there. Yeah, you can play Magic: The Gathering, but you will be playing with a junkie, a tranny, a serial killer and a child molester. I tell you, if Hell is real there aren't any demons there, it's just Hell because it's a giant prison for all the worst humanity has to offer.

posts.com:
I think that the British Film Institute summed up Paul pretty well.
>Paul W.S. Anderson’s Event Horizon (1997) would serve our purposes here, but there’s no way it’s getting picked over his masterpiece, Resident Evil: Retribution. A lithe sugar rush of conceptual and formal experimentalism, the film delivers on the fleetingly glimpsed promise of the previous film (Resident Evil: Afterlife, 2010), itself a welcome surprise given the franchise’s inauspicious origins. For this fifth entry, Anderson throws caution to the wind, dropping any pretence of narrative cohesion for a balls-to-the-wall symphony of movement and abstraction in thrall to its leading lady, Milla Jovovich.
>Anderson has previous in the video game adaptation race, but none come close to Retribution’s thematic engagement with the form. Effectively beginning at Afterlife’s save point, the film sees long-dead characters return as part of an exhaustive conceptual design, an infinite loop of multiple, parallel realities. Video game logic that sees the dead – and the undead – rise to fight again ad infinitum? Sure, but also nifty commentary on the inexhaustible nature of franchise cinema.
Event Horizon is good, but it's the product of a young, hungry, inexperienced director. Also, Anderson wrote some of the better lines, but it isn't Anderson's script. It's only when you combine Anderson's direction with Anderson's script that you get films that truly examine the human condition. I really like Free Guy, but fact is, it's a pale imitation of Resident Evil: Retribution. To understand this monument to videogame cinema is to understand Simulacra and Simulation implicitly.

>right about the time it switches tone (the black guy rocket-packs his way back to the ship "Wah-hooooo!"). So very likely the filmmakers knew it was running on fumes by that point and started going OTT.
No, basically every single Paul W.S. Anderson movie does this. Monster Hunter starts out as a military story, it shifts to a horror story with people being eaten alive by spiders, and then it shifts into an odd couple comedy, and then finally shifts back to a mixture of fantasy and military action.

Death Race shifts between grimdark racing with blood and gore and crushed bodies, and characters saying things like, "Alright cocksucker, fuck with me, and we'll see who shits on the sidewalk." Paul has this subtle love of putting wholly inappropriate sound effects into films such as clonking noises during fight scenes. I think some people don't like that the final fight in Event Horizon is all "clonk, clonk" and had the gall to complain, so Anderson had his revenge by putting loud, comical clonk sounds into every movie. Because fuck the haters, it's his party, and he'll clonk if he wants to.

Black man here, I've been to China - both big cities and middle of fucking nowhere mountains.
People everywhere were surprised to see me but it felt moreso surprised at seeing a foreigner at all.

I've also been to the middle east, war zones, ghettos in dirt-poor African and South American countries, supposed 'no go' zones across Europe - but the only places where I'd feel uneasy walking around when minding my own business are Haiti and the USA.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Video games will never have good stories because they inherently rely on action and player input. The former pigeonholes them into violence and the latter implies an autistic, non-defined person that simultaneously must have their own agency and respect the player controlling them.

>>178974104
Samson was the last of the judges God sent the Israelites to deliver them from the Philistines, hence the story being in the Book of Judges. At that time they were mostly under occupation. He was a Nazirite, an extremely strict sect of Hebrews who followed every commandment to the T. God promised that He would send someone to deliver them from their occupation, and through Samson this was fulfilled. Samson was given what we would call today superhuman strength and endurance. He killed over 1000 men on the battlefield with just a jawbone of a donkey as his weapon. He wrestled a lion and killed it. In accordance with his upbringing, he did not cut his hair ever and was supposed to be strict in observing God's laws. He later proved to basically violate every law there was. He killed, he ate from wild things in the wilderness (they were seen as unclean things to God), and he ended up sleeping with beautiful yet promiscuous women. Eventually, one of the enemy philistine women seduces him and tries to get the secret to his power. Eventually, though mostly aware of these attempts he gives in and tells her his hair is the secret. His hair is cut in his sleep and he awakes to enemy soldiers taking him into custody. Powerless, he's taken into the royal temple of the Philistines. There, the King had many idols and worship dedicated to their pagan god Dagon. They planned to sacrifice Samson to Dagon. Before that they wanted to torture and humiliate him for his previous victories, so they cut his eyes out and made him grind corn or grain (can't remember exactly) with a mortar stone. They then chain him by the arms between two massive pillars in their temple for all the royalty and observing crowd to see, kinda like a trophy display at a grand celebration. They had a pagan feast/orgy before sacrifice. There Samson remembered God for the first time in a long while. Throughout his victories and indulgence in the spoils of them he forgot to be faithful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178974104
>>178975714
(Cont)

Now in his darkest hour, Samson calls out to God. He doesn't ask God to smite the Philistines, nor does he ask to be saved. He asks God to let him die with them. God sends him his strength one last time and Samson brings down the pillars which causes a reaction that destroys the whole temple in moments. He killed more people in that temple than he ever did on the battlefield. And since the philistine leadership was there, Israel had been effectively freed from Philistine occupation, thus fulfilling God's promise. So the point of the story? There's a few; but deep down, Samson realized he wasn't worthy of the strength bestowed to him. He gave into sin many times. Though the mighty strength made him invulnerable, he forgot that it was never really his to begin with. Though his hair had returned, his strength didn't come back until he reached out to God. The point is that it never was about the hair to begin with, it was about the strength that comes when one truly walks with the Lord. And by obeying God's commandments do we walk that road. Like everything else in the OT, this story is a preview of Jesus Christ and what He did and does for us. When you walk with Christ you gain the most power of all, which is eternal life. Samson shows us a picture of Christ in some ways. Christ succeeded where Samson failed, but both shared similarities. Both were sent to liberate their people from the enemy, both did so with their deaths. Both had godly power, but one was stronger than death itself. Both were judges sent by God with a predestined purpose.

>>178971457

Wild elephants are not something you want to be messing with. The bulls are extremely territorial and sometimes they just snap and rampage. Usually younger ones that were booted from a group.

They're smart and trainable, as long as they're kept well fed and watered they're willing to put up with considerable mistreatment. It has happened regularly in the past and it's not a smart approach because they're so powerful.

They aren't exactly top of food chain, they're just sufficiently large and social. Predators will try to go after isolated young ones, but usually only if desperate, it's a very risky thing.

I also knew of a family that lived on a game reserve that had elephants. The old guy that ran it would always chat with the elephants when ever they were around. They never fed them or interfered with what ever they were doing. He eventually became really ill and had to be taken to the Hospital. The entire herd of elephants stood along the driveway watching as his wife drove him off to the Hospital. He eventually died in hospital, and when the wife returned a few days later the elephant family slowly came up to the lodge late one afternoon, carrying sticks and tree branches, one by one laying them in a pile by her car, stood in a group for a moment and then left. The wife was convinced the Elephants knew that her husband was never going to come back, and paid their respects with the logs.

It's bee a long standing suspicion of me that the whole Grogu clone stuff from Mandalorian and the cloning research hints at the end of Bad Batch S1 is more damage control to make the events in the sequel trilogy seem less hare-brained. A real shame, since the little good will built up by the Madalorian and Bad Batch will get besmirched by linking those series to the shitty ST. Back then, they dropped the ball so hard, it would be best that Madalorian and the other series in that timeline should simply finish their stories without extra links to the sequels and then set new movies a few hundred years in the future, where Rey, Finn and the whole shitshow that occurred is all but a myth. Best course of action would be to retcon the ST out of existence, but that would mean they'd have to admit that they fucked it up, which won't happen.
